quiz.title: Unit 5: Perfect Competition (Quiz 10)
quiz.subtitle: AP Microeconomics — Conceptual Review & Long-Run Dynamics
quiz.subject: AP Microeconomics
quiz.topic: Long-Run Equilibrium, Profit Max, Elasticity, Market Adjustments, Firm Behavior

questions.question: In long-run equilibrium in perfect competition, firms produce where:
options: Price equals marginal cost and equals average total cost.
questions.explanation: Long-run equilibrium requires P = MC (profit max) and P = ATC (zero economic profit).

questions.question: When a perfectly competitive firm maximizes profit in the short run, it:
options: May earn profit, break even, or incur loss.
Must shut down if price is below ATC.
Produces where price is greater than marginal cost.
questions.explanation: Short-run profit maximization (P = MC) can result in profit, loss, or breaking even depending on the relationship between price and ATC.

questions.question: The demand curve faced by an individual perfectly competitive firm is:
options: The same as the market demand curve.
questions.explanation: Because the firm is a price taker, it can sell any quantity at the market price, so its demand curve is perfectly elastic (horizontal).

questions.question: If a firm’s minimum efficient scale is very large relative to market demand, the market structure is most likely to become:
questions.explanation: Large minimum efficient scale means only a few firms can operate efficiently, leading to oligopoly or natural monopoly.

questions.question: In the short run, a perfectly competitive firm will shut down if:
options: Price is less than average total cost.
Price is less than average variable cost.
It is incurring any economic loss.
Marginal cost is greater than price.
questions.explanation: Shutdown occurs if P < AVC; the firm cannot cover variable costs and minimizes loss by producing zero.

questions.question: The price elasticity of demand for a perfectly competitive firm’s product is:
questions.explanation: The firm faces a horizontal demand curve, meaning it can sell any quantity at the market price — perfectly elastic demand.

questions.question: If a perfectly competitive firm is producing where P = MC and P = ATC, we know the firm is:
questions.explanation: P = MC means profit maximization; P = ATC means zero economic profit (normal profit).

questions.question: If firms in a perfectly competitive industry are earning economic losses, in the long run:
options: Some firms will exit, reducing supply and raising price.
Demand will increase to restore profit.
questions.explanation: Losses cause exit, which reduces market supply, raises market price, and restores zero economic profit.

questions.question: Which of the following is true for a perfectly competitive firm in both short-run and long-run equilibrium?
questions.explanation: P = MC holds in both short-run and long-run profit maximization. P = ATC only in long-run equilibrium; P = MR always true; MC = ATC only at min ATC.

questions.question: A perfectly competitive market achieves allocative efficiency because:
options: There are many buyers and sellers.
questions.explanation: Allocative efficiency occurs where P = MC, meaning the last unit produced provides a marginal benefit equal to marginal cost.

scoreMessages.90: Excellent command of perfect competition concepts — ready for the AP exam.
scoreMessages.70: Strong understanding; review shutdown rule and LR vs. SR equilibrium.
scoreMessages.50: Fair; revisit elasticity, profit conditions, and market adjustments.
scoreMessages.0: Needs review: key perfect competition principles, especially P=MC and zero-profit condition.
